core_requirements.name: Philosophical Alignment
core_requirements.description: The rule must encode or express a core TrueSignal principle. If a rule is merely useful but not tied to project values (e.g. interpretability, precision, composability), it is not eligible.

core_requirements.name: High Value-to-Complexity Ratio
core_requirements.description: The rule must provide high practical or conceptual value relative to its complexity. Simpler, more universally valuable rules are favored.

core_requirements.name: Durability
core_requirements.description: The rule must remain meaningful across prompt design changes, schema evolution, or model behavior shifts. Fragile rules are ineligible.

core_requirements.name: Testability
core_requirements.description: There must be a clear, automatable way to determine whether the rule is satisfied. Rules requiring subjective judgment without strict definitions are discouraged.

core_requirements.name: Teachable / Self-Revealing
core_requirements.description: The rule should help train or inform a future maintainer. Core rules should clarify system behavior, not just constrain it.

core_requirements.name: Precision & Clarity
core_requirements.description: The rule’s intent must be unambiguous and implementation-ready. Rules with vague or overlapping scopes must be reworded or split.

core_requirements.name: Non-Genericity
core_requirements.description: The rule must not be overly broad or universally applicable (e.g. 'be clear'). Generic guidance belongs elsewhere — not in the core.

core_requirements.name: Independence
core_requirements.description: Whenever possible, the rule should be atomic and not rely on other rules for meaning. Interdependencies should be minimal and explicit.

core_requirements.name: Alignment with Schemas and Standards
core_requirements.description: Core rules must integrate cleanly with TrueSignal’s evolving schemas, validation rules, and prompt composition standards.
